narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Measure Theory and breif taste of ergodic theory

This course covered foundational results of measure theory and functional analysis, going beyond the Lebesgue measure to more exotic measures such as the uniform measure on the Cantor set, and extending many of the results from real analysis to the general setting of locally compact Hausdorff spaces and metric spaces. We covered monotone convergence, Fatou's lemma, and dominated convergence. We learned about the completion of sigma-algebras and weak-star convergence. We derived the Reiz representation theorem. We delved into the fundamental results of Lp spaces, including the Holder and Minkowski inequalities and the completeness of Lp. We used the Lebesgue-Radon-Nykodym derivative to relate sigma-finite measures and discussed the notions of upper and lower derivatives of Radon measures. We touched on Hilbert space theory, including the Freschet-Reiz representation theorem, and we used the RNL derivative to relate complex measures with their total variations. The last two weeks of the course were perhaps the most interesting, where we talked about ergodic theory, including Poincare recurrence and the Birkhoff ergodic theorem.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very, very good! Best teacher and class so far at Yale!

This was a very strong course. The course could be improved by assigning a ULA or a TA. Another suggestion would be to spend less time on the nuts and bolts of theorems such as the Besicovitch covering theorem or the Reiz representation theorem. They were interesting but largely took time away from more interesting measure-theoretic results.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The instructor is very, very good. Clear presentation, excellent explanation in difficult topics, and fun expansion to other relative topics and open questions. I love this course a lot!

I would recommend this course to another student. I took this course without taking real analysis first, and I found the knowledge gap to be manageable. This was a great way to encounter analysis in a more general setting. The topics from this course have many application in statistical mechanics, dynamical systems, and number theory.
